An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
Does the concept of a/an Algebra over a Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Integral Element over a Ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an integral element over a ring involves an element $b \n B$ being integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$. This definition inherently requires a ring homomorphism from $A$ to $B$, but it does not require $B$ to be an algebra over $A$. The definition of an integral element focuses on the existence of a monic polynomial $f \n A[X]$ such that $f(b)=0$, or similar conditions related to $A$-modules, none of which necessitate $B$ being an algebra over $A$. The definition of an algebra over a ring, on the other hand, involves a ring homomorphism from $A$ to $B$ and additional structure related to mappings between algebras, which is not required for defining integral elements. Therefore, while both concepts involve a ring homomorphism, the concept of an algebra over a ring is not necessary for the definition of an integral element over a ring.
